natural solution: We have \begin{align} (n-1) \cdot n &\cdot (n+1) \cdot (n+2) \cdot (n+3)\\ &= (2-1) \cdot 2 \cdot (2+1) \cdot (2+2) \cdot (2+3) \\ &= 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 4 \cdot 5, \end{align} which is equal to $5!$, or $\boxed{120}$.
We could also multiply the last expression out by hand: \begin{align} (1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3) \cdot 4 \cdot 5 &= 6 \cdot 4 \cdot 5 \\ &= 6 \cdot 20 \\ &= 120 . \end{align}
